cards.title: Brazil 2-1 Venezuela / Thiago Silva helps Brazil to advance in Copa América
cards.rawTitle: Thiago Silva helps Brazil to advance in Copa América

item.title: Thiago Silva helps Brazil sink Venezuela to advance in Copa América
item.trailText: Thiago Silva and Roberto Firmino scored early in each half to fire Brazil to a 2-1 win over Venezuela at the Copa América
item.standFirst:
• Brazil 2-1 Venezuela
• Thiago Silva 9, Firmino 52; Fedor Miku 84
item.body:
Thiago Silva and Roberto Firmino scored early in each half to fire Brazil to a 2-1 win over Venezuela at the Copa América on Sunday, sending the five-times world champions into a quarter-final meeting with Paraguay.

Recalled to the side for this match, Thiago Silva opened the scoring for Brazil after nine minutes when the defender volleyed home a corner from Robinho. Firmino doubled their lead six minutes into the second half when he leapt to volley home a cross from Willian on the left.

Miku got a consolation goal for Venezuela six minutes from time when he stooped to head home from close range after Jefferson had touched a free-kick from Juan Arango on to a post.

Last night’s games completed the quarter-final line-up that will see the hosts, Chile, face Uruguay on Wednesday, Peru take on Bolivia on Thursday and Colombia play Argentina on Friday. The Brazil-Paraguay tie will be on Saturday.

displayImages.caption: Roberto Firmino celebrates after putting Brazil two goals up against Venezuela. Photograph: Felipe Trueba/EPA

cards.title: Football / Messi is asked for selfie by Jamaica’s Brown in Copa América
cards.rawTitle: Messi is asked for selfie by Jamaica’s Brown in Copa América

item.title: Messi is asked for selfie by Jamaica’s Deshorn Brown in Copa América
item.trailText: Lionel Messi admitted surprise to request after Argentina win from striker Deshorn Brown who took phone to subs’ bench before match
item.standFirst:
• Messi admits surprise to request after Argentina win
• Striker Brown took phone to subs’ bench before match
item.body:
Lionel Messi is used to being sought after by fans, celebrities and even fellow professionals but he was still caught by surprise when Deshorn Brown, of Jamaica, asked for a selfie following Argentina’s 1-0 win over his team in the Copa AméricaArgentina won Group B with Saturday’s victory, their second at the tournament in Chile, and were waiting on Sunday to find out who they would face in the last eight after the final round of Group C matches.

Related: ‘I would have hit Neymar’: Carlos Bacca’s mother springs to son’s defence

Brown, who had been substituted near the end of the match in Viña del Mar, Chile, picked up his mobile phone as soon as the final whistle went and ran on to the pitch to find Messi.

“I had thought about it before the match so that’s why I took [the phone] to the bench. As soon as [the match] finished … I took the picture,” Brown said.

“Messi is the best in the world, a star, and that’s a photo I’ll have as a souvenir all my life.” Argentina’s captain laughed as he recalled what happened. “He surprised me. On top of that I was annoyed about how the match had gone despite our win … but when I saw the phone I realised what was going on. It’s really nice when a colleague asks me for that,” Messi said. Argentina should have had more than Gonzalo Higuaín’s early goal, hitting the bar twice in the first half before losing the initiative in the final quarter of the match. However, they have now won Group B.

They managed to defend their lead and avoid what happened in their opening match when they gave away a two-goal lead to Paraguay who scored twice in the last half hour for a 2-2 draw.

displayImages.caption: Jamaica's Deshorn Brown takes a selfie with Argentina's Lionel Messi at the  Copa América in Chile. Photograph: Ivan Alvarado/Reuters

cards.title: Italy 0-0 Portugal / Stalemate means England U21s have all to play for
cards.rawTitle: Stalemate means England U21s have all to play for

item.title: Italy and Portugal stalemate means England U21s have all to play for
item.trailText: Italy and Portugal drew 0-0 in Group B of the European Under-21 Championship to leave England with a good chance of qualifying for the semi-finals
item.standFirst: • European Under-21 Championship: Italy 0-0 Portugal
item.body:
Italy’s qualification hopes were left in the balance after a spirited 0-0 draw against Portugal in Uherske Hradiste. Both sides can still progress from Group B but Italy must now defeat England to make the semi-finals.

Italy made five changes after the defeat to Sweden, the coach, Luigi Di Biagio, dropping his captain, Matteo Bianchetti, and the Azzurrini were much improved in their new shape, with a three-man midfield.

The Portugal goalkeeper José Sá was busy early on, palming over Marco Benassi’s shot in the first 15 seconds. Domenico Berardi led the attack, outshining his opposite number Bernardo Silva in the first half. He twice created chance for Andrea Belotti. The first, after six minutes, brought a fine low save from the feet of José Sá and the second intervention by the Portugal No1 left Belotti kicking the post in frustration close to the midway point in the half.

Portugal’s first chance came after 26 minutes when Sérgio Oliveira played the ball back for João Mário, only for the forward to shoot wide.

Italy again pushed at the start of the second half, Belotti diving in bravely ahead of José Sá to flick Cristiano Biraghi’s left-wing cross against the bar. Their best chance came in the dying seconds of added time, when the Italy left-back Biraghi was clean through but could not control the ball to take advantage, leaving the game all square.

displayImages.caption: Italy's Andrea Belotti looks dejected after missing a chance to score the winner against Portugal in their European Under-21 Championship game. Photograph: Carl Recine/Action Images via Reuters

cards.title: Colombia 0-0 Peru / Peru reach last eight of Copa América after goalless draw
cards.rawTitle: Peru reach last eight of Copa América after goalless draw

item.title: Peru into last eight of Copa América after goalless draw with Colombia
item.trailText: Colombia were clinging to hopes of a last-eight place in the Copa América after their goalless draw with Peru, who thus guaranteed their place in the quarter-finals
item.standFirst:
• Colombia 0-0 Peru
• Colombia still have hope of last-eight place
item.body:
Colombia were left sweating on their Copa América hopes after a lacklustre 0-0 draw with Peru on Sunday.

The result took Peru into the quarter-finals but Colombia’s advance is dependent on the result of the day’s later match between Brazil and Venezuela.

Colombia were the better side and the Peruvian keeper, Pedro Gallese, got down well to stop Radamel Falcao opening the scoring in the third minute. Pablo Armero then shot into the side netting after a defence-splitting pass from James Rodríguez.

Jackson Martínez missed a great chance to guarantee Colombia’s advance when he scuffed a weak shot straight at the goalkeeper in injury time.

The draw left both sides with four points in Group C and ended Ecuador’s chances of progressing as one of the two best third-placed teams.

The other two teams in Group C, Brazil and Venezuela, both need to win to guarantee their quarter-final place.

The winner of Group C will play Paraguay in the quarter-finals, while the team in second place will face Bolivia. Uruguay, one of the guaranteed best third-place teams, face the hosts, Chile.

displayImages.caption: Peru players celebrate after the draw with Colombia put them in the last eight of the Copa América. Photograph: Raul Sifuentes/LatinContent/Getty Images

cards.title: Fiorentina / Club appoint Sousa as coach

item.title: Fiorentina appoint Paulo Sousa as coach
item.trailText: Fiorentina have appointed Paulo Sousa as their coach, in place of Vincenzo Montella, who was sacked this month
item.standFirst:
• Former Portugal midfielder has managed QPR, Swansea and Leicester
• Sousa replaces Vincenzo Montella, who was sacked this month
item.body:
Fiorentina have appointed Paulo Sousa as their coach, the Serie A club said on Sunday. The 44-year-old former Portugal midfielder has managed Queens Park Rangers, Swansea City and Leicester City in England, and left the Swiss club Basel last week after a year in the job.

“Fiorentina is delighted to announce that an agreement has today been reached with Paulo Sousa for him to become the new first-team coach,” Fiorentina said in a statement on their website. “Sousa will be in Florence tomorrow to complete the formalities.”

Sousa, who won the Champions League as a player with Juventus and Borussia Dortmund, replaces the former Italy striker Vincenzo Montella. Montella was sacked this month after leading Fiorentina to fourth place in Serie A and the semi-final of the Europa League. He was dismissed, according to the club, for a lack of respect and causing a breakdown in trust with the fans.

displayImages.caption: Paulo Sousa left Basel last week after one week in the job and has now joined Fiorentina. Photograph: Juanjo Martin/EPA

cards.title: Germany 4-1 Sweden / Sasic fires Germany into Women's World Cup quarter-finals
cards.rawTitle: Sasic fires Germany into Women's World Cup quarter-finals

item.title: Celia Sasic fires Germany past Sweden and into World Cup quarter-finals
item.trailText: Germany comfortably reached the quarter-finals of the Women’s World Cup on Saturday when they braved the baking heat to thrash Sweden 4-1 in a second round game
item.standFirst:
• Germany 4-1 Sweden
• Mittag 24, Sasic 36pen 79, Marozsan 88; Sembrant 82
item.body:
Germany comfortably reached the quarter-finals of the Women’s World Cup on Saturday when they braved the baking Ottawa heat to thrash Sweden 4-1 in the last 16.

Celia Sasic scored in each half, with Anja Mittag and Dzsenifer Marozsan also finding the net against an unimpressive Swedish side. Linda Sembrant headed home a late consolation goal for Sweden while Sasic and Mittag now both have five goals in the tournament.

Germany next play the winner of Sunday’s match in Montreal between France and South Korea, at the same venue on Friday.

Related: Women's World Cup 2015 - interactive wallchart

The physically imposing Germany side, who had scored 15 goals in their three group matches, spurned several good chances before Mittag fired in a curling 22-yard drive in the 24th minute.

Sasic easily converted a penalty in the 36th minute and then headed home from close range in the 78th minute. Sembrant grabbed one back for Sweden four minutes later before Marozsan looped the ball over Sweden’s goalkeeper Hedvig Lindahl in the 88th minute.

Germany, who won the title in 2003 and 2007, were knocked out in the quarter-finals when they hosted the tournament in 2011. Sweden came third in that World Cup.

displayImages.caption: Celia Sasic heads her second and Germany's third goal of as comfortablle last-16 victory over Sweden. Photograph: Dennis Grombkowski/Bongarts/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Germany v Sweden: Round of 16 - FIFA Women's World Cup 2015
displayImages.cleanCaption: Celia Sasic heads her second and Germany's third goal of as comfortablle last-16 victory over Sweden. Photograph: Dennis Grombkowski/Bongarts/Getty Images

sublinks.title: England / We can win it all – 100%, says fit-again Taylor
sublinks.rawTitle: We can win it all – 100%, says fit-again Taylor

item.title: ‘England can win Women’s World Cup – 100%,’ says fit-again Jodie Taylor
item.trailText: Striker Jodie Taylor has declared that England can win the Women’s World Cup, having battled back from knee surgery to play a key role in the knockout phase
item.standFirst: Striker confident Mark Sampson’s squad can lift the trophy after battling back from knee surgery to play key role in knockout phase
item.body:
Mark Sampson likes to talk about the weapons contained in his armoury and Jodie Taylor ranks foremost among them. The Portland Thorns striker – the sole member of England’s squad domiciled abroad – underwent knee surgery eight weeks ago and has been nursed back to fitness in the hope of assuming a central role in the knockout phase.

Taylor, a forward that Norway will not be keen to see on the pitch here on Monday, made her World Cup debut as a late substitute in last Wednesday’s 2-1 win over Colombia and very nearly scored. “It was amazing,” she says. “I really enjoyed it. I might have got a goal when I went through just after I’d come on, but the keeper clipped me at the last minute.

“I had a bit of a setback after the surgery on my knee, so I’m just delighted I made it back in time. The staff at St George’s Park were great; they sped up my rehab and it was so reassuring that Mark still believed in me, and selected me for the squad.”

Related: England’s Mark Sampson ready to start fun part of Women’s World Cup

The injury struck out of the blue and at what appeared to be the worst possible time. Right up until the day England checked in at Heathrow for their transatlantic flight the 29-year-old was touch and go. “I got it in training, in Portland, on a Wednesday, but not through contact,” says Taylor.

“The knee just turned – I felt it go. Portland got me in, two days later, for the op, then the following weekend I flew home. From the start of May I was at St George’s Park pretty much the whole time before we flew out here for the World Cup.

“I was in full-time rehab for a couple of weeks before the team came into camp, and even when the players were there I was around them, but still doing my rehab. It was a relief I was able to fly to Canada with the squad. It could easily have gone the other way. But now training’s going really well, I’m getting sharper with every session. I’m definitely ready for matches.”

The Merseysider had been due to make her bow from the bench as a second-half substitute during last Saturday’s 2-1 win over Mexico, but her knee swelled up during a half-time warm up. “It was probably partly a reaction from the training I’ve been doing, taking on increasing loads,” she says. “I did the pre-match warm-up, then I was sitting down for a while and then went back out at half-time to warm up.

“It just didn’t feel right. The doctor took a look and, as desperate as I was to play, you’ve got to know your limits. Fortunately, we think the swelling was just a one off, but against Colombia I didn’t do the pre-match warm-up – I just started mine at half-time.”

Taylor’s increasing trust in her knee is mirrored by a staunch belief in England’s prospects and Sampson’s radical rotation policy. “We’ve grown into the tournament and Colombia was a big win for us,” says the striker, who has played in Australia and Sweden, as well as in the United States, where she has also served as an assistant coach.

“We’re getting better and better. We don’t want to peak too early, but we keep progressing and hitting the targets we’ve set. A lot of players have now got minutes, and that’s key in a tournament. In my opinion you can’t play the same 11 or 12 players in five or six matches – that won’t get you to the final.”

On the subject of England potentially dominating that denouement in Vancouver on 5 July, she is unequivocal. “100%, yes,” says Taylor. “I believe we can win the World Cup.”

cards.title: Football / Liverpool sign Gomez for £3.5m from Charlton
cards.rawTitle: Liverpool sign Gomez for £3.5m from Charlton

item.title: Liverpool announce signing of Joe Gomez from Charlton Athletic
item.trailText: Liverpool have confirmed the signing of Joe Gomez from Charlton for an initial fee of £3.5m
item.standFirst:
• England Under-19 defender says move is a dream come true
• Gomez becomes Liverpool’s fourth signing of the summer
item.body:
Liverpool have confirmed the signing of the England Under-19 defender Joe Gomez from Charlton for £3.5m, becoming the fourth signing of what has already been a busy off-season at Anfield.

Gomez, who turned 18 last month, impressed in his first league campaign at The Valley and joins James Milner, Danny Ings and Adam Bogdan on the list of players to have signed with Brendan Rodgers’ team since last season, when they finished sixth, eight points adrift of the Champions League places.

Related: ‘Caged lion’ Fabio Borini wants to leave Liverpool, claims agent

“It’s a dream come true,” Gomez told Liverpool’s website after passing a medical. “It’s a bit surreal and it hasn’t really hit me yet. But I’m buzzing and just excited to get started. The club has got great history and it’s a great club, and one that I’ve always been following from when I was young. The style of football and the top players here was somewhere that I wanted to go and get better and learn, and play good football. It was an easy decision.”

Though used most often at right-back last season, Gomez spent much of his time in the Charlton academy as a centre-half, having joined the club as a 10-year-old. He signed a three-year deal last year but it is understood it contained a £3.5m release clause. “I’ve been here since I was 10 years old and it’s been a great experience,” he added. “The club have always looked after me and I will always be grateful.

“I’m excited for the new challenge at Liverpool and it’s an opportunity that I’ve only been given thanks to the experience that Charlton have given me.”

The completion of the deal might now pave the way for Sebastián Coates to make a permanent move from Anfield to Sunderland, having spent last season on loan there. Coates is on international duty at the Copa América with Uruguay.

Luis Alberto is set to return to Anfield, after his two-year loan deal with Málaga was reportedly cut short by the Spanish club, having made only six starts in La Liga last season. Alberto cost £6.8m when signing from Sevilla in 2013 but the 22-year-old midfielder started only two games for Liverpool – against Notts County and Oldham – before moving to southern Spain. He is unlikely to be part of Rodgers’ plans and may be loaned out again if the club cannot find a buyer.

displayImages.caption: Liverpool's latest signing Joe Gomez made 24 appearances for Charlton last season having made his debut soon after his 17th birthday. Photograph: JMP/REX Shutterstock
